data.name: Tic-Tac-Toe Checker (Harder)
data.description:
This kata serves as a more general case of this one. If you didn't - you probably should start with solving it first.

Intro

OK, checking for a state of the game in 3x3 Tic-Tac-Toe (TTT for short) is easy, but how about 4x4? 20x20? 100x100? 1000x1000? Obviously, there's a reason why TTT board is 3x3 - it's the perfect size for a quick, simple game; anything larger than that would change the game to a boring, ridiculously elongated and almost impossible to win caricature. But what does it matter to a computer?

Task

As you probably guessed by now - the task of this kata is very similar to the original one, the only difference being the board size. The function should accept a single argument, `board`, which will be a NxN list (`3 <= N <= 1500`), like this one: ``` [[0, 0, 1], # 0 - empty [0, 1, 2], # 1 - X [2, 1, 0]] # 2 - O ``` which represents a state of a TTT game, in the above case: ``` - - X - X O O X - ``` and return a single integer: - `-1` if the board is not yet finished (there are empty spots), - `1` if "X" won, - `2` if "O" won, - `0` if it's a cat's game (i.e. a draw) - no further moves are possible.

Details

We will generalize the winning conditions to be the same for every size of the board, so: any full horizontal row of a single symbol, any full vertical row of a single symbol and any of the two diagonals full of a single symbol. For a standard 3x3 there are 8 winning states (3 horizontals, 3 verticals and 2 diagonals), and we can easily see that for a NxN game this number is 2*N+2. As you may expect, the size of the board quickly disqualifies the simpler, iterative algorithms, so you probably need to be a little more creative to pass the tests.
